column3: U-33 (Kptlt. Hans-Wilhelm von Dresky). Sunk on 12 February 1940 in the Firth of Clyde
column8: by depth charges from the British minesweeper HMS Gleaner.

column3: U-104 (Kptlt. Harald Jürst). Sunk on or about 28 November 1940 in the North Atlantic north-west of Tory Island
column6: by a mine in the British minefield SN 44.

column3: U-772 (Kptlt. Ewald Rademacher). Sunk on 17 December 1944 in the Celtic Sea south of Cork
column7: by depth charges from the British frigate HMS Nyasaland.

column3: U-1051 (Oblt. Heinrich von Holleben). Sunk on 26 January 1945 in the Irish Sea south of the Isle of Man
column6: by ramming and depth charges from the British frigates HMS Aylmer

column3: U-1172 (Oblt. Jürgen Kuhlmann). Sunk on 27 January 1945 in St George\'s Channel
column6: by depth charges from the British frigates HMS Tyler

column3: U-1014 (Oblt. Wolfgang Glaser). Sunk on 4 February 1945 in the North Channel east of Malin Head
column6: by depth charges from the British frigates HMS Loch Scavaig

column3: U-1276 (Oblt. Karl-Heinz Wendt). Sunk on 20 February 1945 in the Celtic Sea south of Waterford
column6: by depth charges from the British sloop HMS Amethyst.

column3: U-1302 (Kptlt. Wolfgang Herwartz). Sunk on 7 March 1945 in St George\'s Channel
column6: by depth charges from the Canadian frigates HMCS La Hulloise

column3: U-296 (Kptlt. Karl-Heinz Rasch). Sunk on or about 12 March 1945 in the western entrance of the Northern Channel
column6: by a mine in the British minefields T1 or T2.

column3: U-246 (Kptlt. Ernst Raabe). Sunk on 17 March 1945 in the Irish Sea south of the Isle of Man
column7: by depth charges from the British ASW trawler HMS Lady Madeleine.

column3: U-1003 (Oblt. (R) Werner Strübing). Scuttled on 23 March 1945 in the Northern Channel north of Malin Head
column6: after ramming with Canadian frigate HMCS New Glasgow in position 55.25N

column3: U-242 (Oblt. Heinz Riedel). Sunk at 0715hrs on 5 April 1945 in the St. George’s Channel
column8: by a mine in the British barrage QZX.

column3: U-1024 (Kptlt. Hans-Joachim Gutteck). Captured on 12 April 1945 in the Irish Sea south of Isle of Man
column6: by the British frigates HMS Loch Glendhu and HMS Loch More. The boat was taken in tow by the frigates but it foundered in position 53.43
